title: 112_s3084
content: The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" is the short title of the Act. It deals with the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" amends the Veterans Integrated Service Networks by organizing the Veterans Health Administration into 12 geographically defined networks aligned with the Department's mission and specific healthcare requirements of veterans. Each network must implement national goals and maintain a regional integrated healthcare system. The Secretary ensures that each Veterans Integrated Service Network maintains a regional integrated healthcare system by implementing alliances with other healthcare organizations, managing a regional budget aligned with Department guidelines, and using national metrics for effective healthcare delivery. The Secretary ensures that each Veterans Integrated Service Network reduces duplicate functions and collaborates for maximum effectiveness in patient care. The Secretary ensures collaboration and cooperation among Veterans Integrated Service Networks to maximize patient care effectiveness and assess consolidation of functions with other entities. The Secretary oversees collaboration among various entities, including Department of Defense offices, Coast Guard facilities, state and local agencies assisting veterans, medical schools, government offices, emergency preparedness organizations, community and faith-based organizations, and other federal government offices. Additionally, the Secretary promotes the development and sharing of innovations and practices. The Secretary ensures collaboration among various entities, including emergency preparedness organizations, community and faith-based organizations, and other federal government offices. The Veterans Integrated Service Networks develop and share innovations and best practices at local, regional, and national levels. Each network has one headquarters office co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center, with a limited number of employees and contractors. The Secretary reports to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs annually. The Secretary may employ up to 65 full-time equivalent employees and contractors at each Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters. An annual report on employment must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs, including the number of individuals employed, titles of positions, and details on employment within the network. The Secretary may employ up to 65 full-time equivalent employees and contractors at each Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters. A triennial review and assessment of the structure and operations of the Networks must be conducted, with a report submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary must conduct a triennial review of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks' structure and operations, submitting a report with recommendations to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. This includes combining specific networks into single entities to comply with the new structure. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is consolidating multiple Veterans Integrated Service Networks into single entities to comply with the new structure outlined in the Act. This includes combining various networks such as VISN 4 and VISN 5, VISN 9 and VISN 10, VISN 11 and VISN 12, VISN 15 and VISN 23, VISN 17 and VISN 18, and VISN 19. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is consolidating multiple Veterans Integrated Service Networks into single entities as outlined in the Act. This includes combining VISN 17 and VISN 18, VISN 19 and VISN 20, and VISN 21 and VISN 22 into single networks. Headquarters of the consolidated networks will be retained in their current locations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is consolidating multiple Veterans Integrated Service Networks into single entities as outlined in the Act. Headquarters of the consolidated networks will be retained in their current locations, and reemployment assistance will be provided for individuals whose positions are eliminated. The Secretary must submit an implementation plan within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will assist in finding new employment within the Department of Veterans Affairs for individuals whose positions are eliminated. The Secretary may relocate headquarters offices to be co-located with medical centers as required by the Act. The Secretary may relocate headquarters offices to be co-located with medical centers as required by the Act. If renewing or entering into a new lease, a report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs detailing the reasons for such actions. The report should include a list of underutilized medical centers in the Veterans Integrated Service Network. Before renewing or engaging in a lease, a report must be submitted detailing the reasons for such actions. The report should include a list of underutilized medical centers in the Veterans Integrated Service Network, the cost of the current lease, and the cost of the new lease. SEC. 3. REGIONAL SUPPORT CENTERS FOR VETERANS INTEGRATED SERVICE NETWORKS. The Secretary shall establish up to four regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will evaluate finance operations, compliance activities, and outreach efforts to veterans who served in specific military operations. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. This includes assessing outreach to veterans of specific military operations, programs for women veterans, homelessness programs, energy consumption, and other relevant operations. Staff may be hired as needed for these assessments. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate the operations and activities of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Staff may be hired as needed, and the location of each center will be determined by the Secretary, typically co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. If a center is not co-located, a report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs explaining the reasons for the chosen location. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate Veterans Integrated Service Networks. A report must be submitted if a center is not co-located with a VA medical center, detailing reasons for the location choice, including cost and square footage of the lease. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The initial staffing will involve transferring employees from headquarters to regional support centers. A clerical amendment will be made to the table of sections in the title. The Act establishes regional support centers for Veterans Integrated Service Networks, without requiring changes to existing medical care facilities under the Department of Veterans Affairs.
